label.value: angle-resolved ion-excited Auger electron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where ion bombardment of a sample results in the ionisation of core electrons and the emission of so-called 'Auger' electrons, which are detected as a function of emission angle.

label.value: scanning Auger electron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where a high-energy photon beam is scanned over the surface of a sample resulting in the ionisation of core electrons and the emission of so-called 'Auger' electrons. The energies of these Auger electrons are detected as a function of incident photon energy.

label.value: spin-polarised Auger electron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the bombardment of a sample with high-energy photons results in the ionisation of core electrons and the emission of so-called 'Auger' electrons. The energies of these Auger electrons are detected as a function of incident photon energy and a magnet is used to align all electron spins parallel to the emitting surface.

label.value: spin-polarised angle-resolved Auger electron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the bombardment of a sample with high-energy photons results in the ionisation of core electrons and the emission of so-called 'Auger' electrons. The energies of these Auger electrons are detected as a function of emission angle and a magnet is used to align all electron spins parallel to the emitting surface.

label.value: X-ray excited Auger electron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where X-ray bombardment of a sample results in the ionisation of core electrons and the emission of so-called 'Auger' electrons, which are detected as a function of incident X-ray energy.

label.value: continuous X-ray-induced Auger electron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the bombardment of a sample with a continuous X-ray source (X-rays generated when electrons, or other high energy charged particles such as protons or alpha-particles, lose energy whilst passing through the Coulomb field of a nucleus) results in the ionisation of core electrons and the emission of so-called 'Auger' electrons, which are detected.

label.value: transmission electron energy loss spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where a beam of electrons with a known, narrow range of kinetic energies is transmitted through a sample and the energy distribution of the transmitted electrons is measured.

label.value: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the sample is illuminated with X-rays causing ionisation and the emission of photoelectrons, the energies of which are measured.

label.value: angle-resolved X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the sample is illuminated with X-rays causing ionisation and the emission of photoelectrons, which are detected as a function of emission angle.

label.value: high-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the sample is illuminated with monochromatic X-rays causing ionisation and the emission of photoelectrons, the energies of which are measured.

label.value: soft X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the sample is illuminated with 'soft' (<300 eV) X-rays causing ionisation and the emission of photoelectrons, the energies of which are measured.

label.value: high-resolution soft X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the sample is illuminated with monochromatic 'soft' (<300 eV) X-rays causing ionisation and the emission of photoelectrons, the energies of which are measured.

label.value: nuclear activation analysis

value.value: A type of activation analysis where atomic nuclei are excited (by a heavy ion beam or by collision with another nucleus) and their decaying gamma-ray emissions are measured and compared to reference spectra.

label.value: inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Plasma mass spectrometry where the plasma has been generated by electromagnetic induction.

label.value: electrothermal vaporisation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Plasma mass spectrometry where the sample is vaporised by depositing it on a probe which is rapidly heated (to >1000 deg C) by passing a current through it.

label.value: slurry electrothermal vaporisation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: ETV-ICP-MS where the solid sample is prepared by grinding into a fine powder and suspension in a diluent such as 0.1% HNO3.

label.value: slurry nebulisation electrothermal vaporisation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where a solid sample is ground to a fine powder and suspended in a diluent (such as 0.1% HNO3) before being vaporised by a probe which is rapidly heated by passing a current through it. The vaporised sample is ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction.

label.value: solid sampling electrothermal vaporisation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where a solid sample is vaporised by depositing it on a probe which is rapidly heated by passing a current through it. The vaporised sample is ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction.

label.value: high performance liquid chromatography-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by high-performance liquid chromatography before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction, and characterised by mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: high-performance liquid chromatography fluorescence detection-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by high-performance liquid chromatography with fluorescence detection before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction, and characterised according to mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: high-performance liquid chromatography photodiode array-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by high-performance liquid chromatography with photodiode array detection before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction, and characterised according to mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: high-resolution inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where the sample is ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction. The 'exact' mass of the sample ions is then determined as opposed to the 'nominal' mass (the number of protons and neutrons).

label.value: inductively coupled plasma field sector mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where the sample is ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction. The beam of ions is then directed into magnetic field, the orientation of which is perpendicular to the beam. The magnetic field forces the charged particles into different circular trajectories, the radii of which depend on the strength of the magnetic field, the accelerating voltage, and the mass of the ion.

label.value: inductively coupled plasma three dimensional quadrupole mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where the sample is ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction. The mass-to-charge ratio of the sample ions is then measured whilst the ions are held in a stable orbit by an electric field generated by three electrodes.

label.value: inductively coupled plasma time-of-flight mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where the sample is ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction. The sample ions with different masses are then accelerated to the same (known) kinetic energy and the time taken for each ion to reach a detector at a known distance is measured.

label.value: laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where the sample is vaporised using a laser pulse then ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction.

label.value: laser ablation inductively coupled plasma time-of-flight mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where the sample is vaporised using a laser pulse then ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction. The sample ions with different masses are then accelerated to the same (known) kinetic energy and the time taken for each ion to reach a detector at a known distance is measured.

label.value: liquid chromatography-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by liquid chromatography before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction, and characterised by mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: multiple collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where the sample is ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction. A series of collectors ised used to detect several ion beams simultaneously.

label.value: size-exclusion chromatography-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by size-exclusion chromatography before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction, and characterised by mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: size-exclusion chromatography-high-performance liquid chromatography-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by size-exclusion and high-performance liquid chromatographies before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction, and characterised by mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: solution inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where a sample mixture (a solution in dilute HNO3) is ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction.

label.value: solution nebulisation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where a sample mixture (a solution in dilute HNO3) is passed through a nebuliser to form a mist of finely dispersed droplets before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction.

label.value: time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where the sample is bombarded with a stream of primary mass-selected particles and the secondary ions ejected from the sample are detected by accelerating them to the same (known) kinetic energy and measuring the time taken for each ion to reach a detector at a known distance. This time is dependent on the mass-to-charge ratio of the ion.

label.value: diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the diffuse reflection of a single pulse of infrared radiation by a sample is measured, and the spectrum obtained is subject to a Fourier transform.

label.value: tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy

value.value: Spectroscopy where the Raman scattering of monochromatic light, from a visible laser (500–650 nm), by metal surfaces, where scattering is enhanced by the optical near-field of a metal-coated scanning probe microscopy tip, is detected.

label.value: thermogravimetry

value.value: The measurement of the mass of a sample as a function of temperature.

label.value: liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry

definition.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by liquid chromatography before being ionised and characterised by mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance using two mass spectrometers in series.

label.value: capillary electrophoresis-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where a sample mixture is first separated by capillary electrophoresis, before being ionised in a plasma which has been generated by electromagnetic induction and characterised according to mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: capillary liquid chromatography-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by capillary liquid chromatography before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction and characterised according to mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: neutron activation analysis

value.value: A type of activation analysis where a sample is bombarded with neutrons, the capture of which results in the generation of radioactive nuclei for most elements in the sample. These activated nuclei then decay according to their characteristic half-lives.

label.value: thermogravimetry-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy

value.value: The FTIR analysis of volatile compounds released during the measurement of the mass of a sample as a function of temperature.

label.value: thermogravimetry-mass spectrometry

value.value: The MS analysis of volatile compounds released during the measurement of the mass of a sample as a function of temperature.

label.value: dynamic reaction cell inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: Mass spectrometry where the sample is ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction. The sample is held in a dynamic reaction cell which contains a reagent gas that reacts preferentially with certain species, in order to allow only the analyte ions into the mass-to-charge analyser and the detector.

label.value: gas chromatography-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by gas chromatography before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction, and characterised according to mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: ion-exchange chromatography-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

value.value: A method where a sample mixture is first separated by ion-exchange chromatography before being ionised in a plasma (a partially ionised gas–-such as Ar–-containing free electrons) which has been generated by electromagnetic induction, and characterised according to mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.

label.value: elemental analysis

value.value: A process where a sample is analyzed for its elemental and sometimes isotopic composition (the elements present and sometimes their weight percentage).

label.value: carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen elemental analysis

value.value: A type of elemental analysis accomplished by combustion of the sample at 1200 °C in a stream of unreactive gas and excess oxygen and collection of the products (CO2, H2O and NOx). The masses of these combustion products can be used to calculate the composition of the unknown sample.

label.value: osmometry

value.value: The measurement of the osmotic strength of a substance which often used to determine its molecular weight.

label.value: vapour pressure osmometry

value.value: A technique used to determine the concentration of osmotically active particles that reduce the vapor pressure of a solution. Vapour pressure osmometry is used to measure the average molecular weight of polymers.
